title: 111_hr6517
content:
The Omnibus Trade Act of 2010 is cited as the short title for this Act. It includes extensions of trade adjustment assistance and health coverage improvement. Subtitle B of the Omnibus Trade Act of 2010 focuses on Health Coverage Improvement, including measures to improve the affordability of credits, payment for monthly premiums, eligibility for credits for TAA recipients not in training programs, rules for pre-certification periods, qualification of family members, extension of COBRA benefits, addition of coverage through voluntary employees' beneficiary associations, and notice requirements. Additionally, Title II extends the Andean Trade Preference Act, and Title III addresses offsets. The text chunk discusses the extension of the Andean Trade Preference Act, customs user fees, time for payment of corporate estimated taxes, compliance with PAYGO, and the extension of Trade Adjustment Assistance and Health Coverage Improvement. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 is amended to extend the application of prior laws starting February 13, 2011. This includes changes to the Trade Act of 1974, with specific adjustments to section 245. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 is amended to extend the application of prior laws starting February 13, 2011, with specific adjustments to sections 246, 256, and 298 of the Trade Act of 1974. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 is amended to extend the application of prior laws from December 31, 2007, to February 12, 2011. Assistance under chapter 3 cannot be provided after February 12, 2012, except for previously approved assistance if funds are available and the recipient is eligible. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 is amended to extend the application of prior laws until February 12, 2011. Assistance under chapter 6 cannot be provided after February 12, 2012, except for previously approved assistance if funds are available and the recipient is eligible. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 is amended to extend funding limits until February 12, 2011. The authorized appropriations for fiscal year 2010 and the 6-week period starting January 1, 2011, are specified in the amendments. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 is amended to extend funding limits until February 12, 2011, with specified appropriations for fiscal year 2010 and the 6-week period starting January 1, 2011. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 is amended to extend funding limits until February 12, 2011, with specified appropriations for fiscal year 2010 and the 6-week period starting January 1, 2011. Amendments include changes to funding amounts and timelines for various sections of the Trade Act of 1974. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 is amended to extend funding limits until February 12, 2011, with specified appropriations for fiscal year 2010 and a 6-week period starting January 1, 2011. Amendments include changes to funding amounts and timelines for various sections of the Trade Act of 1974. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 is amended to extend funding limits until February 12, 2011, with specified appropriations for fiscal year 2010 and a 6-week period starting January 1, 2011. Amendments include changes to funding amounts and timelines for various sections of the Trade Act of 1974, such as section 298(a) and the table of contents. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 is amended to extend funding limits until February 12, 2011, with specified appropriations for fiscal year 2010 and a 6-week period starting January 1, 2011. Amendments include changes to funding amounts and timelines for various sections of the Trade Act of 1974. SEC. 111 amends the Internal Revenue Code to change the effective date to February 13, 2011. SEC. 112 adjusts the payment for monthly premiums effective February 13, 2011. SEC. 113 allows TAA recipients not enrolled in training programs to be eligible for credit. SEC. 113 allows TAA recipients not enrolled in training programs to be eligible for credit, effective for coverage months beginning after December 31, 2010. SEC. 114 amends various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, ERISA, and PHSA to change the effective date to February 13, 2011 for determining creditable coverage lapses. SEC. 115 amends the Internal Revenue Code and the Workforce Investment Act to change the effective date to February 13, 2011 for continued qualification of family members after certain events. SEC. 116 extends COBRA benefits for certain TAA-eligible individuals and PBGC recipients by changing the effective date to February 12, 2011. SEC. 117 amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend coverage through voluntary employees' beneficiary associations by changing the effective date to February 13, 2012. SEC. 118 amends the Internal Revenue Code to update notice requirements with an effective date of February 13, 2011 for certificates issued after December 31, 2010. The Andean Trade Preferences Act is extended for Colombia and Peru, with different expiration dates. Ecuador's extension date is also adjusted. Certain apparel articles' treatment date is changed. The annual report frequency is modified to be submitted annually instead of every 2 years. TITLE III--OFFSETS

SEC. 301. Customs user fees are amended with new dates. SEC. 302. Corporate estimated taxes payment time is increased by 4.5 percentage points.

TITLE IV--BUDGETARY EFFECTS SEC. 401 of TITLE IV states that the budgetary effects of the Act must comply with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The determination will be based on the latest statement submitted by the Chairman of the Senate Budget Committee before the vote on passage.
